thread.title: ECB Ready to Use All Available Means in Greek Crisis, Visco Says
thread.title_full: ECB Ready to Use All Available Means in Greek Crisis, Visco Says - Bloomberg Business

author: Sonia Sirletti
title: ECB Ready to Use All Available Means in Greek Crisis, Visco Says
text:
The European Central Bank is ready to use all means at its disposal in the Greek financial crisis, Governing Council Member Ignazio Visco said.
“The council is following attentively the developments on the financial markets and the implications for monetary conditions of the area and for price stability, and is ready to use all intstruments at its disposal,” Visco, who is also governor of the Bank of Italy, said in a speech Wednesday.
European leaders set a Sunday deadline for Greece to accept a rescue, saying otherwise they’ll take the unprecedented step of propelling the country out of the euro. This weekend now looms as the climax of a five-year battle to contain Greece’s debts, potentially splintering a currency that was meant to be unbreakable.
“The direct effects of the Greek crisis, for the path of the commercial and financial links, should be modest for Italy and for the region even in the worst scenarios, Visco told the Italian Banking Association’s annual meeting in Rome. ‘‘The crisis will, however, have more serious repercussions if it rekindles in investors the fear that the euro isn’t irreversible.”
The consequences of Greece’s possible euro exit are weighing on Italian banks’ stock prices, as the country’s sovereign bonds, mostly held by them, are perceived riskier by investors. While lenders have limited direct exposure to Greece, their holdings of Italy’s government bonds stood near a record high of 415.5 billion euros ($458.7 billion) in April.
“The interruption of negotiations between Greece and its international creditors, and the results of last Sunday’s referendum, have had on the whole limited consequences so far on financial markets of the euro area,” Visco said.
The spread between Italy’s 10-year BTP and the benchmark German 10-year bund has widened 39 basis points since June 26, the day before the Greek referendum was announced. The yield on Italian 10-year debt has risen to 2.26 percent from a low of 1.13 percent in March.
